clinical_study.brief_title: A Digital Approach to Improving Carbohydrate Periodisation Behaviours in Elite Athletes : A SMART+ Study
clinical_study.official_title: Digital Approaches to Improve Carbohydrate Periodisation Behaviour in Elite Athletes With a Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomised Trial Design.

brief_summary.textblock:
The carbohydrate periodisation framework is a widely accepted nutritional intervention strategy in the field of sports nutrition. However, despite the validity of this approach, it is reported that athletes find it difficult to stick to this behaviour and that the support required is highly personalised, and as a result time consuming for the coach. Prior research has suggested that a digital environment can deliver better personalised dietary interventions to better support athletes.
The overall purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness of a mobile (MP app) approach against a non-digital (control) approach to improve dietary carbohydrate periodisation behaviours in elite athletes over a 12 week period. The study also aims to gain wider understanding of the context and implementation of the mobile approach, and how the addition of adaptive coach support interventions (Call, MesC, MesP) can further increase the effectiveness of the mobile approach.

detailed_description.textblock:
The non-digital (control) group and mobile group are separately recruited in a 1 : 2 ratio. Participants in the non-digital (control) group will receive no intervention from the research team for 12 weeks. Participants in the mobile group will receive the menu planner app (MP) intervention for 12 weeks.
For participants receiving MP in the mobile group, a multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) design will be implemented. Participants will be randomized, by teams, to a Mobile(static) arm or a Mobile(adaptive) arm using a 1:1 allocation ratio. In the Mobile(static) arm, no coach support interventions will be given (participants have the MP only for 12 weeks).
In the Mobile(adaptive) arm, participants will receive coach support interventions (Call+MesC, MesC, or MesP) sequentially. Participants will be assessed at week 4 and week 8 and be categorised as responders (R1 and R2 respectively) and non-responders (NR1 and NR2). There will be a maximum of two randomisation points at week 4 and week 8 depending on whether they are responders or non-responders.
Stage 1: Participants will first receive Call+MesC for 4 weeks and will be categorised as responder (R1) or non-responders (NR1) at week 4.
Stage 2a: Non-responders to stage 1 (NR1) will repeat Call+MesC for the next 4 weeks.
Stage 3a: At week 8, if NR1 participant is a responder (R2), reduce to MesC for another 4 weeks; if participant is a non-responder (NR2), repeat Call+MesC for another 4 weeks.
Stage 2b: Responders to stage 1 (R1) will be re-randomised to receive either MesC or MesP for the next 4 weeks.
Stage 3ba: At week 8 for R1 participants receiving MesC, if participant is a responder (R2), continue MesC for another 4 weeks; if participant is a non-responder (NR2), go back to Call+MesC for another 4 weeks.
Stage 3bb: At week 8 for R1 participants receiving MesP, if participant is a responder (R2), continue MesP for another 4 weeks; if participant is a non-responder (NR2), re-randomise participant to receive either MesC or Call+MesC for another 4 weeks.
All re-randomisations are done at 1:1 allocation ratio.

primary_outcome.measure: Success rates of carbohydrate periodisation behaviour at week 12
primary_outcome.description: A binary success of whether dietary periodisation behaviour has improved in the participant measured by the "periodisation behaviour questionnaire" (in the process of submitting the paper on validation of questionnaire). The scale is 1- does not periodise, 2-periodises energy but not carbohydrate, and 3-periodises both. Higher score indicates better periodisation behaviour. Only score of 3 is considered success.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in dietary self-efficacy from baseline to week 12.
secondary_outcome.description: The dietary self-efficacy will be assessed using a self-efficacy scale. This questionnaire have been validated in the general population (Stich, Knauper and Tint, 2009). The scale is a 5-point scale from 1 for not confident at all, to 5 for very confident. Higher score indicates higher self-efficacy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in beliefs about consequences from baseline to week 12.
secondary_outcome.description: The beliefs about consequences scale has not yet been validated but has been adapted from previous research on beliefs about capabiilities by Wallin, Bostr√∂m and Gustavsson (2012). The scale is a 5-point sale from 1- not at all to 5- extremely. Higher scores indicate higher beliefs about consequences.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in body weight from baseline to week 12.
secondary_outcome.description: Self-reported weight (in kg/lbs) collected at baseline and at week 12.

other_outcome.measure: Personality traits on a BFI-2S questionnaire at baseline
other_outcome.description: The BFI-2S questionnaire (Soto and John, 2017) is a validated questionnaire to assess the Big Five Personality domains of an individual.

other_outcome.measure: Level of need for autonomy on the nutrition causality orientation scale at baseline.
other_outcome.description: The nutrition causality orientation scale is a measure of the need for autonomy in nutrition-related decisions. It is not yet validated but is adapted from previous research on the validated health causality orientation scale (Smit and Bol, 2020). The scale is a 7-point scale, with 1 being strongly disagree to 7 being strongly agree.

other_outcome.measure: Weekly frequency of text messages for 12 weeks.
other_outcome.description: The messaging frequency from the coach to the participant, and the messaging frequency from the participant to the coach every week, for participants assigned to Mobile (adaptive) groups.

arm_group.description: Participants who currently receive performance nutrition support, via a qualified practitioner as indicated by a member of the sports science team at their sporting organisation, will be assigned to the non-digital approach (control). These participants will not receive any intervention from the research team for the duration of this study (12 weeks).

Participants who currently do not receive performance nutrition support as above will be eligible for randomisation to this group. Participants will be given access to an app-based menu planner (MP) for 12, where they self-report their adherence to the menu plan via a tick system in-app.

Participants who currently do not receive performance nutrition support will be eligible for randomisation. Participants will be given access to an app-based menu planner (MP) for 12 weeks, where they self-report their adherence to the menu plan via a tick system in-app. In addition, in the first 4 weeks, the participants will receive Call_MesC, which consists of one nutrition coach phone call (Call) and active coach-led text messaging twice a week (MesC).

For participants in Mobile (adaptive), after 4 weeks of intervention, this group of participants will discontinue the Call_MesC, and receive participant-led (ad-hoc) messaging (MesP) for the next 8 weeks (week 5-12). Note the MP is given for the whole 12 weeks duration.

For participants in Mobile (adaptive), after 4 weeks of intervention, this group of participants will discontinue the Call_MesC, and receive participant-led (ad-hoc) messaging (MesP) for the next 4 weeks (week 5-8), then receive MesC for the subsequent 4 weeks (week 9 -12). Note the MP is given for the whole 12 weeks duration.

Note the MP is given for the whole 12 weeks duration.

intervention.description: The app-based menu planner (MP) given to the participants has an automated carbohydrate periodisation menu planning tool, an educational and motivational nutrition content (infographics, video and text articles), and recipes. Participants using the app will input their training schedule into the app to produce their own menu plans. The behaviour change techniques (BCT) underlying the intervention are goal & planning, feedback & monitoring, shaping knowledge, natural consequences, comparison of behaviour, comparison of outcome, associations, repetitions, reward & threat, regulation and antecedents. The intermediate assessment of the intervention, is estimated by the adherence to the MP via a tick box system in the app. Participants with more than 60% adherence at end of week 4 and end of week 8 of using the MP are considered responders (R1 and R2 respectively), otherwise they are non-responders (NR1,NR2).

A 30-45 minutes coaching consultation telephone/Skype call from the nutrition coaching once every 4 weeks to give social support. The BCT underlying the intervention is goal & planning, social support, natural consequences.

Nutrition coach-led messaging (MesC) is where the mobile app (MP) has the text messaging feature activated, and the nutrition coach proactively initiates a conversation via text messaging twice a week to offer nutrition support to the participant. The BCT underlying the intervention is goal & planning, social support, natural consequences.

Participant led messaging (MesP) is where the mobile app (MP) has the messaging feature activated, the participant can initiate a conversation via text message with the nutrition coach to seek nutrition support. The coach will not initiate any conversation as in MesC, the participant will have to be the first to engage to receive support from the coach.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Have access to a personal smart phone.
- An elite athlete competing at the highest level of domestic or international competition in an intermittent sport, e.g. football, rugby, hurling etc.
- Have a performance related weight loss or weight maintenance physical goal.
- Do not have or have not have a history of eating disorders or disordered eating.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants with a medically diagnosed history of eating disorders or disordered eating will be asked to self-exclude from the study.
